Context:
Program Name: Fashion Techniques and Design
Code: F113
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,596.00 *
International Tuition: $18,322.00 **
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Method of Study: Full-time
Centre: Arts, Design & Information Technology
School: Fashion & Jewellery
Program Type: Women's wear program
Core Subjects: Technical illustration, pattern making, pattern grading, clothing construction, textiles, technical specifications, history of costume.
Electives: Allows students to select specific related subject areas.
Semester 1, 3 (Fall 2023) and Semester 1, 2, 4 (Winter 2024): On Campus delivery.

* Domestic tuition fee may vary based on additional fees and other factors.
** International tuition fee may vary based on additional fees and living expenses.

Context:
The Fashion Techniques and Design program at the School of Fashion and Jewellery offers various related subject areas as electives, including fashion show development, portfolio development, draping, lingerie, men's pattern drafting, leather apparel, knitwear, and bridal and evening wear. Students are expected to have access to a personal laptop or desktop computer, printer, and reliable Internet for classes.

The program covers introductory methods to advanced concepts in the second year and provides opportunities for students to network with industry, participate in competitions, work on applied research projects, volunteer, and attend industry events. Extensive sewing experience and access to a sewing machine outside of campus facilities are required.

Graduates of this program may find career opportunities in various roles such as pattern drafting or construction, drafting and construction specifications, product development, assistant designers, technical designers, patternmakers, samplemakers, assistant apparel technicians, graders, marker makers, technical illustrators, product developers, stylists, design, trend and style consultants, and social media. Graduates with a minimum program GPA of 2.7 are eligible for admission to George Brown postgraduate programs.

The learning environment at the School of Fashion and Jewellery is diverse, and there are many extracurricular activities to take advantage of. The fashion show and portfolio event highlight successful student projects. The program requires students to study through the spring/summer semester and continue into the September academic year for a duration of 1.5 years for those starting in January. Both manual dexterity and good vision are assets for this program. Career opportunities range from small design studios to large manufacturing companies, and some graduates have also become entrepreneurs in design, sewing, and fashion service bureaus.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Fashion Techniques and Design Program F113 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Extracted Information:
- The program requires a grade point average of 3.5 or higher for admission into fashion programs at other post-secondary institutions.
- Transfer Guide can be found for further information.

Semester 1 Courses:
- FASH 1033: Technical Illustration
- FASH 1082: World of Fashion
- FASH 1107: Fabric Science: Textiles
- FASH 1115: Fundamental Pattern Drafting
- FASH 1117: Construction I – Theory and Practice
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts

Semester 2 Courses:
- FASH 1031: Fabric Analysis
- FASH 1061: Torso Drafting
- FASH 1122: Construction II: Theory and Practice
- FASH 1153: Technical Specifications and Development
- FASH 1159: Design and Colour for Fashion
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3 Courses:
- FASH 2038: Advanced Torso Drafting
- FASH 2056: Construction III – Theory and Practice
- FASH 2064: Pattern Grading and Marker Making
- Program Elective (choices vary, examples include FASH 2082: Fashion Journalism – An Introduction, FASH 1252: Fashion Business Communication, FASH 1002: P.D.S. (Pattern Drafting System), and FASH 1008: Visual Merchandising)
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 4 Courses:
- FASH 1091: History of Costume
- FASH 2046: Construction IV – Theory and Practice
- FASH 2051: Advanced Drafting
- Program Elective (choices vary, examples include FASH 2082: Fashion Journalism – An Introduction, FASH 1252: Fashion Business Communication, FASH 1002: P.D.S. (Pattern Drafting System), and FASH 1008: Visual Merchandising)
- GNED: General Education Elective

Placement test results may require students to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000. COMM 1000 does not count as a course required for graduation and will incur additional charges.

General Education Electives are required, and their choices vary from semester to semester. Examples include FASH 2082: Fashion Journalism – An Introduction, FASH 1252: Fashion Business Communication, FASH 1002: P.D.S. (Pattern Drafting System), and FASH 1008: Visual Merchandising.

Context:
Program Offered: Visual Merchandising with courses including FASH 1084 (Visual Merchandising), FASH 1125 (Fashion Promotion and Advertising), FASH 1132 (Block Making), FASH 1134 (Collection Development), FASH 1135 (Independent Study), FASH 2050 (Draping), FASH 2053 (Men's Pattern Drafting), FASH 2054 (Portfolio Development), FASH 2065 (Bridal and Evening Wear), FASH 2076 (Fashion Project and Event Planning), FASH 2077 (Knitwear Product Development), FASH 2078 (Surface Textile Design), FASH 2081 (Introduction to Apparel Fit), and elective courses FASH 1090 (Independent Study – Field Education) and FASH 1229 (Costume Production for Film and Theatre).

Tuition & Fees: Domestic students pay $4,596.00 in tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022. International students pay $18,322.00 in tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023. Tuition fees do not include books and additional supplies which must be purchased separately.

Course Outlines: Detailed course outlines are available.

Articulation Agreement: Graduates may be eligible for further study in other academic institutions.

Learning Outcomes: Graduates will be able to draft and grade flat patterns for mass garment production, select and use production methods and techniques that best suit the fabric, pattern and design of the garments, select garment materials that are compatible with the overall apparel design and meet the user's needs, operate industrial sewing, pressing, grading and other technical equipment safely to professional standards, apply technical and computing skills to fashion design and production, research and analyze factors, trends, stylistic features and art principles that influence current fashions, prepare visual and portfolio materials, product specifications and cost analysis for a product, project and/or market, and design, prototype and produce original patterns and garments using mass production industrial methods and equipment.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Fashion Techniques and Design Program F113 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program-specific information:
- This program requires extensive sewing and drafting experience.
- It is strongly recommended that applicants have sewing experience.
- Students who enter the program with intermediate experience in working with commercial patterns and construction of garments have a better chance to succeed in program demands.
- Both sewing ability and access to a sewing machine outside of the campus facilities are expected.
- Basic computer literacy and skill level in Word and Excel are recommended.

Admission requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- Grade 12 English (C or U)
- Grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math, or consider upgrading to achieve the credits needed in English and math.

Application process:
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
- International Students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact information:
- School of Fashion and Jewellery: Phone: 416-415-5000, ext. 4840; Email: fashionandjewellery@

Additional notes:
- International Students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
- Financial Assistance is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.
- Meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to the program.
- Students who start the program in January (winter term) will be required to attend classes during the summer months (May to August).
- Course exemptions can be achieved through college or university credits. Please visit the Transfer Guide for more information.
- International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
